me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder2.geometry

Interface LinearEquation

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.io.Serializable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    PointSlope, SlopeIntercept

    public interface LinearEquation
extends java.io.Serializable
    A representation of a linear equation. A linear equation is a first-degree function, meaning the highest power X is raised to is 1. Linear equations are used for - you guessed it - Lines! You can also do some other math with them, but I just haven't found a use for it yet. So yeah.
    Since:
    0.1.0
    Author:
    Colin Robertson

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      double getIntercept()
      Get the equation's intercept with the Y axis.
      PointXY getIntersection(LinearEquation equation)
      Get the point of intersection between this equation and another LinearEquation.
      PointXY getPoint()
      Get the line's "point." This is mostly useful for vertical lines.
      PointXY getPoint(double x)
      Get a point based on an X value.
      double getSlope()
      Get the line's slope.
      double getVertical()
      If the line is vertical, get the line's X position.
      double getY(double x)
      Get a Y value at a specific X value according to the equation.
      boolean intersectsWith(LinearEquation equation)
      Check if two equations intersect.
      boolean isVertical()
      Is the line vertical, meaning it has a slope of +- infinity?

    • Method Detail

      • getY

        double getY(double x)
        Get a Y value at a specific X value according to the equation.
        Parameters:
        x - the X value to "look up."
        Returns:
        the Y value, according to the inputted X value.

      • getPoint

        PointXY getPoint(double x)
        Get a point based on an X value.
        Parameters:
        x - the X value to "look up."
        Returns:
        the point, according to the inputted X value.

      • getPoint

        PointXY getPoint()
        Get the line's "point." This is mostly useful for vertical lines.

        The line's "point" can be any point along the line.

        Returns:
        the line's "point."

      • getSlope

        double getSlope()
        Get the line's slope.
        Returns:
        the line's slope, as a double.

      • getIntercept

        double getIntercept()
        Get the equation's intercept with the Y axis.

        getY(double) with an input of 0 returns the same number as this method.

        Returns:
        the equation's intercept with the Y axis.

      • isVertical

        boolean isVertical()
        Is the line vertical, meaning it has a slope of +- infinity?
        Returns:
        true if the line is vertical, otherwise, false.

      • getVertical

        double getVertical()
        If the line is vertical, get the line's X position.

        If the line is not vertical, return 0.0.

        Returns:
        the line's X position.

      • getIntersection

        PointXY getIntersection(LinearEquation equation)
        Get the point of intersection between this equation and another LinearEquation. If the lines do not intersect (say, for example, they're parallel lines) this method should return null. This method does not take into account domain or range - any intersection between the two lines is considered valid and will be returned.
        Parameters:
        equation - the other equation.
        Returns:
        the point of intersection between the two equations. If the equations do not intersect (if they have parallel slopes) this method will return null instead of a point.

      • intersectsWith

        boolean intersectsWith(LinearEquation equation)
        Check if two equations intersect. This should, generally, always return true unless the equations are parallel.
        Parameters:
        equation - the equation to test.
        Returns:
        if the equations intersect, true. Otherwise, false.
